column2: Sentences for the Word that are used in tests to fill in the blanks with the Word. Make the sentences grade appropriate. K-2 3 sentences, 3-8 is 5 senteces.
column3: DO NOT FILL THIS COLUMN FOR VERSION 1. Alternate words used in tests for sentence completion (need 3 words for every sentence)
column4: Definition for the Word for used in tests to match the Word with its definition. Use definition that is grade approprite.
column5: Spelling alternatives used in tests on spelling. Search to see if we can get examples of common mis-spellings. WE NEED 3 MISSPELLINGS.
column6: Synonyms. These do not need to grade specific.
column7: Antonyms. These do not need to grade specific.
column8: Homonyms. These do not need to grade specific.
column9: Audio file with correct American pronounciation.

column2: The king had absolute authority over his subjects.
column4: (n.) the power or right to give orders, make decisions, and enforce obedience; a person or body of people with power; an expert

column2: My friends did not like how the teacher was trying to exert his authority over his students.
He spoke as if he was some sort of authority on the subject.
Henry was not used to having this authority challenged.
Sarah did not have the authority to fire employees at the firm.
When my mother was a child, she never questioned the authority of her parents.
In many schools, the principal is regarded as the utmost authority figure.
Substitute teachers always excessively try to exert authority over the whole classroom.
If I ever challenge my mother's authority, she starts to go off on a tangent about my disrespect.
Lower level employees do not have the authority to answer questions about highly confidential projects.
Larry tries to play devils advocate in all conversations to start arguments
column4: (v.) to speak or write in favor of; support or urge by argument; recommend publicly

column2: My friends and I are all strong advocates for equality among girls and boys.
column4: (n.) a person who speaks or writes in support or defense of a person, cause, etc. (usually followed by of)

column2: Any good doctor will advocate healthy eating for his patients.
Since Jason is an advocate of living a healthy life, I find it quite surprising he smokes cigarettes.
As a teacher, I am a strong advocate for more parent involvement in schools.
Rather than complain about the laws of your country, you should advocate for them to be changed.
Because my lawyer was such a fierce advocate for me, I won my court case.
Speakers advocate trying new methods to increase sales, improve margins.
If you don't like it, advocate for changing it, not canceling it.
What she really is is an advocate, not a leader.
Ballerinas are supposed to be agile to dance to the best of their ability
column4: (adj.) quick and well-coordinated in movement; lithe

column2: However, being the child of parents who spent their working lives in foreign postings, I became socially very agile.
In fact, monkeys are very agile climbers, using their long tails to balance.
All cats are nimble and agile, and their long tails aid their outstanding balance.
The mind is not as agile as it once was as someone ages, even at the ripe old age of 34.
Mustangs are wild, tough and agile.
The university's mission is to develop leaders through agile and innovative programs embracing theory and practice.
The lacemaker's wrinkled hands are surprisingly agile.
Nutria are large, web-footed rodents that are more agile in the water than on land.
We need to evolve and keep our minds and bodies agile.
He could not but view Ali in the light of an accomplice, because if, as he protested, he did not abet the murderers, yet he took them under his protection.
column4: (v.) to encourage, support, or countenance by aid or approval, usually in wrongdoing

column2: You are certainly not abetting the person breaking into your system.
The photo editing software is sure to abet my odds of winning the photo competition.
Can you believe the community has decided to abet crime by not giving the police the names of suspected gang members?
Giving the dog a treat is a way to abet his obedience.
During the press conference, the president vowed severe consequences for any person or group who chose to abet the terrorists.
To abet continued gaming, most casinos provide guests with frequent player rewards.
Although Carol claims to support Jay’s filmmaking efforts, she has done nothing to abet his goals.
Isn’t it rather ironic that a doctor would go out of his way to abet a suicide?
The grandmother was arrested for trying to abet her grandson, a prison escapee.
The tears stopped of their own accord after a while, and the calm of her mind brought back her focus.
column4: (v.) to be in agreement or harmony; agree; to make agree or correspond; adapt; to grant; bestow

column2: The parasympathetic division works in accord with mute right-brain intuition.
column4: (n.) proper relationship or proportion; harmony

column2: In accord with his wishes, the logo was engraved on his tombstone.
Yet these reforms are necessary, and they will not happen of their own accord.
Apple's products were designed to accord with the boss's tastes and to meet his obsessively high standards.
But the economists argue that this approach to measuring hunger also does not accord with how people themselves think about it.
This was rejected, however, and full constitutional recognition was accorded to them.
The necklace suggests that the deceased had been accorded high status.
We will not, by fasting, accord him a dignity and sensitivity that he does not possess.
Uncritical compliments are not in accord with the facts.
While Fred, and to a lesser extent Cynthia, had solved cryptograms in the newspaper, neither were particularly adept at it.
column4: (adj.) very skilled; proficient; expert

column2: It doesn't look like you're all that adept at talking to him either.
Indeed, the human brain is more adept at comparing lengths than areas.
Daily training at these schools was focused on becoming adept in the use of the sword, bow and arrow, spear and tonki.
He became so adept with the brush that his paintings show more spontaneity than most of his contemporaries.
One of America's most lucid critics of poetry, uniquely adept at close reading, is also among the genre's great advocates.
Few societies would be as adept at handling these events with as much social cohesion.
While her books are not overly descriptive, they are adept in conveying sense of place.
The brand, actually, has become pretty adept at coming up with wraps that celebrate various holidays.
Dogs, those self-domesticated wolves, are adept at manipulating their chosen companions.

column4: (v.) to divide or distribute by share or portion; distribute or parcel out; apportion; to appropriate for a special purpose

column2: Ben will allot them each a fortress within this small kingdom, and then the game can begin.
You can even allot more bandwidth to movie files so the picture won't stutter.
Instead of giving cash to local operators on trafficking routes, they would allot them a share of the shipment.
Intent and effort toward holistic living is more important than trying to allot equal time to different parts of life.
What he sees in short supply is the time that most people allot to accomplishing something worthwhile.
Not every museum has space the size of a football field to allot to a one-person show.
In each case, that was as much time as the candidates would allot.
Comments are invited on the formula used to allot funds to the outlying areas.
Keep the smile on your face because you have allot to share with so many people.
To the Greeks the gods seemed equally close and equally aloof.
column4: (adv.) at a distance, especially in feeling or interest; apart

column2: His avuncular manner and unpredictable chuckle made him the antithesis of an aloof scientist.
column4: (adj.) reserved or reticent; indifferent; disinterested:

column2: That humility made her approachable rather than aloof .
More mysterious was his aloof management style within his own team.
She appeared aloof and sometimes refused to shake hands with admirers.
She found them aloof and difficult to contact, however, because none of them posted office hours.
However aloof they may seem, they're not indifferent.
He was friendly but aloof, a thoughtful fellow toiling in the shade of mystique.
For years science has maintained a rather aloof stance toward domestic animals in general, and toward dogs in particular.
Contemporaries often found him aloof, standoffish, and cantankerous and his mannerisms and diction inscrutable.
They also discuss typical side-effects of surgery, the signs when something's going amiss and what to expect during recovery.
column4: (adv.) out of the right or proper course, order, or condition; improperly; wrongly; astray

column2: Things really do go bump in the dark, and the baby and family dog figure out that something is amiss long before the adults do.
column4: (adj.) improper; wrong; faulty:

column2: There is something seriously amiss here and it has nothing to do with science.
When a dog is on the street alone, we assume something's amiss.
The only thing amiss is the out-dated system that moves the money to the content creators.
If they are incorrect, they assume something is amiss with the universe, which is unlikely.
It's possible to point out something amiss without judging the people concerned.
But often there is something amiss when a middle-income country has such a rich currency.
In the case presented, this was the first sign that something was amiss: the patient was not breathing properly.
What makes a property flip illegal is when there is something amiss in the transaction.
Most espionage fiction of recent years bears a conscious analogy to a chess game.
column4: (n.) a similarity between like features of two things, on which a comparison may be based

column2: The analogy of a high-wire walker inspires women to find order in their lives.
She drew an analogy between this enterprise and the local infatuation with all things 80's.
The analogy between cars and computers can't be taken too far.
The advantage of a sports analogy is respect for accurate reporting of facts.
A more apt analogy would be an aquarium or a zoo: a place for special trips.
In the Biblical perspective, man's love is an imperfect analogy, marred by sin, of God's perfect and self-giving love.
In her poem, the poet used the analogy of comparing love to an endless well.
My grandmother has a church analogy for every situation that has occurred in her life.
When my brother made a vulgar analogy in health class, he got afterschool detention.
If we are not frightened of total anarchy, we do not need the controlling authority.
column4:
(n.) a state of society without government or law;
political and social disorder due to the absence of governmental control

column2: The Internet may be the most successful example of anarchy ever known.
These small disputes could spawn regional warfare and promote anarchy.
Lawyers, of all people, should agree that law and order are preferable to anarchy.
Plainly the central idea of secession is the essence of anarchy.
Even after his release, the downward trajectory of his life continues, while the country itself plunges toward anarchy.
Pirate life seemed a medley of indulgence and strict equity, mockery and idealism, anarchy and discipline.
They accused me of instigating anarchy and refusing to obey the law.
And indeed there's a significant chance that they will indeed collapse and the country will devolve into anarchy.
But the result is neither lawless anarchy, the war of all against all, nor the tyrannical abrogation of law.
He has managed to avoid teenage antics in residence halls, since.
column4:
(n.) a playful trick or prank, caper;
a grotesque, fantastic, or ludicrous gesture, act, or posture.

column2: The antics of the cubs and the show of affection by the lionesses was amazing to watch up close.
Their antics set the treetops in motion, shaking and swaying along the shore as if they had sprung to life.
The idea was that you'd draw attention to yourself with your outrage and your outrageous antics.
All of the office interns went out for drinks and such tonight and had a group chuckle about the antics of the hiring committee.
Being a lawyer makes a judge partial to a lawyers antics.
Thats the smile of a patient teacher familiar with the antics of rowdy students.
All our critters get names for reasons related to personal affinities and animal antics.
We have a twenty month golden retriever, full of energy and life and funny antics.
They sit around in the coffee shop drinking tea and chuckling over the antics of the reporters.
Orders had been sent to apprehend the fugitives.
column4: (v.) to take into custody; arrest by legal warrant or authority; to grasp the meaning of, understand, especially intuitively, perceive; to understand.

column2: During that time the police failed to apprehend the man.
All people believe they apprehend the world in a rational way.
Baseball is considerably less difficult to apprehend than long division or decimals.
It is the embracing and domination of a situation in order to apprehend the cosmos by process of coming to terms with it.
City officials immediately set efforts in motion to apprehend the wrongly accused man in prison.
When the police showed up at the apartment to apprehend the stolen property, they found the drugs too.
US border authorities no longer apprehend illegal immigrants only as they enter the country.
If the police are called the police should come ready to apprehend the intruder.
Then events race out ahead of thought and word, which stumble blindly behind in a world they cannot apprehend.
The young cosmetics salesman now is discovering that women are ardent shoppers.
column4: (adj.) having, expressive of, or characterized by intense feeling, passionate, fervent; intensely devoted, eager, or enthusiastic, zealous

column2: The software is not flawless, even its most ardent supporters admit.
Yet even ardent critics of the government admit that much has improved.
The residents at Marco's apartment complex are a soccer-crazed nation's most ardent fans.
Those peaceful remarks have not satisfied even the most ardent opponents of the war.
Ardent label readers scan nutritional labels for ingredients that they don't want in their diet.
His ardent backers spout not ideology, but faith in his goodness.
We always look forward to a new administration with ardent anticipations.
Early ardent sentiments of piety seemed to have prevented in her the use of reason.
Ardent environmentalists and hardened sceptics recycle at the same rate.
Learning how to articulate a question is an important life skill.
column4:
(adj.) uttered clearly in distinct syllables;
capable of speech; not speechless.

column2: He is well-dressed, articulate and eager to escape.
column4: (v.) to utter clearly and distinctly; pronounce with clarity; to pronounce clearly each of a succession of speech sounds, syllables, or words, enunciate

column2: I'm struggling to articulate my thoughts as well.
The tour was fascinating and the people couldn't have been nicer or more articulate.
The president is more articulate than he is often held to be, but he is not an orator.
Eric is bright, articulate, and seems utterly at peace with himself and the world.
He's able to articulate what local weavers need and want and what travelers need and want.
It would take me a long time to articulate my thoughts into words.
His biggest failure, however, is his inability to articulate a plausible alternative to the system he loathes.
Instead of banning words, radio bosses would do better to hire more engaging and articulate presenters.
Some critics were quick to assail the new policy as inadequate.
column4: (v.) to attack vigorously or violently, assault; to attack with arguments, criticism, ridicule, abuse, etc.

column2: The thing to remember when such fears assail you is that bad health is not inevitable at any age.
She did this to defend herself, and not to assail the plaintiff.
If anyone ever talks negatively about Alex’s father, his response is to assail the person with insults.
When difficult circumstances assail my tranquility, I turn to meditation.
Anthony can assimilate without discarding his heritage.
column4: (v.) to take in and incorporate as one's own, absorb; to bring into conformity with the customs, attitudes, etc., of a group, nation, or the like, adapt or adjust, to conform or adjust to the customs, attitudes, etc., of a group, nation, or the like

column2: Regular reading and thinking about the style and mechanics will help you assimilate important language skills.
Cultures lacking depth are more easily able to assimilate newcomers.

column4: (n.) the quality or state of being atrocious; an atrocious act, thing, or circumstance.

(v.) to make larger; enlarge in size, number, strength, or extent; increase
(v.) to be of use or value to; profit; advantage:
(n.) advantage; use; efficacy; effective use in the achievement of a goal or objective:
(adj.) showing great enthusiasm for or interest in; extremely desirous (often followed by for or sometimes of)
(adj.) with a turn or twist to one side; askew; away from the expected or proper direction; amiss; wrong
(adj.) mild and refreshing; soft; soothing; aromatic; fragrant
(n.) an exchange of light, playful, teasing remarks; good-natured raillery.
(v.) tease, chaff

(n.) the act or practice of bartering.
(adj.) having a kindly disposition, gracious; showing or expressive of gentleness or kindness
(adj.) markedly unusual in appearance, style, or general character and often involving incongruous or unexpected elements; outrageously or whimsically strange; odd
(adj.) indifferent to or bored with life; unimpressed, as or as if from an excess of worldly pleasures.

(adj.) liberal in bestowing gifts, favors, or bounties; munificent; generous; abundant; ample
(n.) a hiding place, especially one in the ground, for ammunition, food, treasures, etc.
